articles.headline: 2016’s Winning Investors Talk About 2017, and Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Investors who made the correct — and often bold — calls of last year see opportunities in the uncharted waters of the year ahead.
articles.abstract: Investors who made the correct — and often bold — calls of last year see opportunities in the uncharted waters of the year ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year was one of unusually big surprises for markets — none more so than the election of Donald Trump. Not only were many money managers and experts dead wrong about his chances, but they were doubly wrong in betting on a big market sell-off in the event he won.

articles.headline: Farmer on Trial Defends Smuggling Migrants: ‘I Am a Frenchman.’
articles.snippet: Cédric Herrou has become something of a folk hero in France for resisting the state and taking a stand: that it is simply right to help migrants seeking a better life.
articles.abstract: Cédric Herrou has become something of a folk hero in France for resisting the state and taking a stand: that it is simply right to help migrants seeking a better life.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICE, France — At times it was hard to know who was on trial, the smuggler or the state.

articles.headline: Countering Trump, Bipartisan Voices Strongly Affirm Findings on Russian Hacking
articles.snippet: In a hearing, top intelligence officials and senators of both parties pushed back forcefully in a display that seemed directed solely at President-elect Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: In a hearing, top intelligence officials and senators of both parties pushed back forcefully in a display that seemed directed solely at President-elect Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A united front of top intelligence officials and senators from both parties on Thursday forcefully reaffirmed the conclusion that the Russian government used hacking and leaks to try to influence the presidential election, directly rebuffing President-elect Donald J. Trump’s repeated questioning of Russia’s role.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Scott Shane

articles.headline: 4 Black Suspects Charged in Videotaped Beating of White Teenager in Chicago
articles.snippet: The charges, including hate crimes and aggravated assault, came two days after the victim was found wandering in distress on the city’s West Side.
articles.abstract: The charges, including hate crimes and aggravated assault, came two days after the victim was found wandering in distress on the city’s West Side.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A white teenager cowers in a corner, his hands bound with orange cords and his mouth covered with tape. Four African-Americans kick and hit him and slash at his scalp. As a cellphone camera captures their blurry images and broadcasts the ordeal on Facebook, the attackers hurl racial insults and denounce President-elect Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Sensing Gains Ahead Under Trump, the Kochs Court Minorities
articles.snippet: Anticipating a fossil fuel resurgence, the ultraconservative brothers, who run an oil and petroleum conglomerate, are busily expanding their outreach.
articles.abstract: Anticipating a fossil fuel resurgence, the ultraconservative brothers, who run an oil and petroleum conglomerate, are busily expanding their outreach.
articles.lead_paragraph: The crowd that thronged a gospel concert last month in Richmond, Va., was in for an unusual Christmas treat.

articles.headline: Department Stores, Once Anchors at Malls, Become Millstones
articles.snippet: Macy’s and Sears have recently announced numerous closings, reflecting a climate in which online and discount retailers have outmaneuvered them.
articles.abstract: Macy’s and Sears have recently announced numerous closings, reflecting a climate in which online and discount retailers have outmaneuvered them.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, a corner spot at the mall was a sure path to success for big American department stores like Macy’s. Not anymore.

articles.headline: Where Trump Sees Economic ‘Disaster,’ Experts See Something More Complex
articles.snippet: Data suggests many of the nation’s economic fundamentals are solid, and economists say the president-elect’s agenda won’t alter the more worrisome trend lines.
articles.abstract: Data suggests many of the nation’s economic fundamentals are solid, and economists say the president-elect’s agenda won’t alter the more worrisome trend lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has called the American economy a “disaster.” But in Sioux Falls, S.D., Scott Lawrence, a local businessman and Trump voter, has a different take.

articles.headline: Recovery Finally Yields Big Gains for Average Worker’s Pay
articles.snippet: Average hourly earnings rose by 2.9 percent last year, the best performance since the recession, even as job growth tapered off in December.
articles.abstract: Average hourly earnings rose by 2.9 percent last year, the best performance since the recession, even as job growth tapered off in December.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a long time coming — eight years, in fact — but the economic recovery is finally showing up in the average American worker’s paycheck in a big way.

articles.headline: For Millennials, It’s Never Too Early to Save for Retirement
articles.snippet: A snapshot of five millennials shows that some of them are very serious about saving for retirement, busting the myth that their age group is free-spending.
articles.abstract: A snapshot of five millennials shows that some of them are very serious about saving for retirement, busting the myth that their age group is free-spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: You have probably heard it yourself: the impression that millennials are financial freewheelers. The theory goes that today’s 20- or 30-somethings spend with little regard for savings and even less regard for retiring.

articles.headline: How to Pounce on Best Credit Card Offers (Before Banks Pull Them)
articles.snippet: Even if you thought you’d had enough of card-hopping, you might consider grabbing one of those eye-popping sign-up bonuses.
articles.abstract: Even if you thought you’d had enough of card-hopping, you might consider grabbing one of those eye-popping sign-up bonuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: While many of us weren’t paying attention, some credit card sign-up bonuses became so eye-poppingly large that the analysts at Bernstein Research wondered in November if the industry was afflicted with temporary insanity.

articles.headline: He Helped Topple a Dictator. In New York, He’s Another Face in the Crowd.
articles.snippet: Souleymane Guengueng was tortured and imprisoned in Chad. He has experienced financial troubles and bad luck in the Bronx. But he is not giving up.
articles.abstract: Souleymane Guengueng was tortured and imprisoned in Chad. He has experienced financial troubles and bad luck in the Bronx. But he is not giving up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every public housing complex in America is filled with individual tales of struggle and survival. This is the story of a dapper man in a black fedora who lives in unit 16G in the Bronx.
